item.title: Water Sources in Africa
item.description:
we are going to be looking at the water sources in Africa. The data used is from one of the TidyTuesday datasets and it can be retrieved from here. We are going to look analyzing likert scaled dataset. This is going to be split into a 2 parts with the first one looking at the Exploratory data analysis and the other at the variable association and regression. The data can be retrieved from here.

The data is focused on the 5 key attributes of one’s big 5 personalities that is ; Openness,Neuroticism, Agreeableness,Extraversion, Conscientiousness

## Reading layer `africa_shapefile' from data source `C:\Users\Brian Stephen Ssali\OneDrive\Scripts\Others\Portifolio\brianstefans.github.io\content\post\2021-06-09-water-sources-in-africa\Data\africa_shapefile.shp' using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
## Simple feature collection with 55 features and 11 fields
## geometry type:  MULTIPOLYGON
## dimension:      XY
## bbox:           xmin: -17.53017 ymin: -46.98138 xmax: 51.41551 ymax: 37.56095
## geographic CRS: WGS 84

Water sources across africa

item.title: Analysing Likert Scaled Data
item.description:
We are going to look analyzing likert scaled dataset. This is going to be split into a 2 parts with the first one looking at the Exploratory data analysis and the other at the variable association and regression. The data can be retrieved from here.

The data is focused on the 5 key attributes of one’s big 5 personalities that is ; Openness,Neuroticism, Agreeableness,Extraversion, Conscientiousness

Exploring the dataset

We shall now do some exploration of the variables within the dataset to be able to understand it better. First we look at the demographics to understand the distribution and origins of the respondents. We shall be using the skim function from the skimr package and the summary function for a quick EDA.

Table 1: Data summary
Name Piped data
Number of rows 19852
Number of columns 8
_______________________
Column type frequency:
factor 7
numeric 1
________________________
Group variables None

Variable type: factor

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate ordered n_unique top_counts
race 0 1 FALSE 14 Cau: 10641, Oth: 2555, Sou: 1871, Cau: 1521
english_native_language 0 1 FALSE 3 Yes: 12391, No: 7391, mis: 70
gender 0 1 FALSE 4 Fem: 12055, Mal: 7671, Oth: 102, mis: 24
hand_for_usage 0 1 FALSE 4 Rig: 17541, Lef: 1737, Bot: 474, mis: 100
source 0 1 FALSE 5 Ano: 12182, Goo: 3690, Oth: 3538, Fac: 305
country 69 1 FALSE 143 Uni: 8753, Gab: 1531, Ind: 1464, Aus: 994
region 69 1 FALSE 5 Ame: 10791, Asi: 3487, Eur: 3016, Afr: 2288

Variable type: numeric

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist
age 9 1 26.29 11.57 13 18 22 31 118 ▇▂▁▁▁

##  Median : 22.00                           Other :   97   Right:17391

There are some columns with missing values. For these specific values we shall do away with them. We also observe that that majority of the respondents are Caucasians from Europe. A bigger percentage of the respondents are females and majority use the right hand for usage. Also more responses were received from the american region.

We now focus on the 5 attributes starting with Extraversion. We are going to be using the

A bigger percentage of the respondents are females and majority use the right hand for usage. Also more responses were received from the american region.

We now focus on the 5 attributes starting with Extraversion. We are going to be using the

item.title: #Tidytuesday Cracking Passwords
item.description:
We are going to look a dataset from the Tidytuesday on the passwords. The dataset entails the actual text of the password,the category of the password,time taken to crack the password(both online and offline) and the strength of the password.

Exploring the dataset

We use the skimr package to have a quick overview of the data with all the data types.

library(skimr)
skimr::skim(passwords)
(#tab:overview_of_dataset )Data summary
Name passwords
Number of rows 507
Number of columns 9
_______________________
Column type frequency:
character 3
numeric 6
________________________
Group variables None

Variable type: character

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate min max empty n_unique whitespace
password 7 0.99 4 9 0 500 0
category 7 0.99 4 19 0 10 0
time_unit 7 0.99 4 7 0 7 0

Variable type: numeric

skim_variable n_missing complete_rate mean sd p0 p25 p50 p75 p100 hist
rank 7 0.99 250.50 144.48 1.00 125.75 250.50 375.25 500.00 ▇▇▇▇▇
value 7 0.99 5.60 8.44 1.29 3.43 3.72 3.72 92.27 ▇▁▁▁▁
offline_crack_sec 7 0.99 0.50 2.66 0.00 0.00 0.00 0.08 29.27 ▇▁▁▁▁
rank_alt 7 0.99 251.22 145.05 1.00 125.75 251.50 376.25 502.00 ▇▇▇▇▇
strength 7 0.99 7.43 5.42 0.00 6.00 7.00 8.00 48.00 ▇▁▁▁▁
font_size 7 0.99 10.30 3.65 0.00 10.00 11.00 11.00 28.00 ▁▇▁▁▁

There are some rows with NAs that we are going to remove.It would be interesting to see the how long the passwords take to be cracked based on their corresponding categories and their strength as well


plot1 <- passwords %>%
  filter(!is.na(category)) %>%
  mutate(time_unit = factor(time_unit, levels = c("seconds", "minutes", "hours", "days", "weeks", "months", "years"))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(category, value, fill = time_unit)) +
  geom_point(aes(colour = time_unit), size = 2.5) +
  coord_polar(clip = "on") +
  theme_dark() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom", axis.text = element_text(colour = "black"), panel.grid.major = element_line("gray")) +
  scale_colour_manual(values = c("#FFDB6D", "#C4961A", "#F4EDCA", "#D16103", "#00AFBB", "#4E84C4", "#FC4E07"), guide = guide_legend(nrow = 1))

plot1

passwords %>%
  filter(!is.na(category)) %>%
  group_by(category) %>%
  transmute(strength = mean(strength, na.rm = T)) %>%
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c(strength)) %>%
  arrange(value) %>%
  distinct(.) %>%
  ggplot(aes(value, reorder(category, value), fill = name)) +
  geom_segment(aes(xend = 0, yend = category)) +
  geom_point(size = 4, aes(color = category), show.legend = F) +
  geom_text(aes(label = round(value, 1)), hjust = -.5) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Strenght of Password", y = "Category of Password")


passwords %>%
  filter(!is.na(password)) %>%
  mutate(
    num_digits = str_count(password, "\\d"), num_char = str_count(password, "\\D"), no_digits_char = str_count(password, "[^\\d] | [^\\D]"),
    type_of_pwd = case_when(num_digits == 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Character only", num_digits > 0 & num_char == 0 ~ "Numeric only", num_digits > 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Both Character & Numeric")
  ) %>%
  count(category, type_of_pwd, name = "Freq") %>%
  ggplot(aes(Freq, category, fill = type_of_pwd)) +
  geom_col(width = .5, position = "dodge") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
  labs(x = "Category of Password", y = "Frequecy") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("#00AFBB", "#4E84C4", "#FC4E07"))

Looks like majority of the passwords consist of only character values. Some of the password-related and sport related passwords have both the numeric and characters.The nerdy-pop passwords have the least number of passwords with numeric and simple-alphanumeric have the highest number of passwords with only numeric and also with both the numeric and characters.

passwords %>%
  filter(!is.na(password)) %>%
  mutate(
    num_digits = str_count(password, "\\d"), num_char = str_count(password, "\\D"), no_digits_char = str_count(password, "[^\\d] | [^\\D]"),
    type_of_pwd = case_when(num_digits == 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Character only", num_digits > 0 & num_char == 0 ~ "Numeric only", num_digits > 0 & num_char > 0 ~ "Both Character & Numeric"),
    labz = case_when(value > 75 ~ password, TRUE ~ "")
  ) %>%
  group_by(type_of_pwd, time_unit) %>%
  summarise(value = mean(value, na.rm = T)) %>%
  mutate(time_unit = factor(time_unit, levels = c("seconds", "minutes", "hours", "days", "weeks", "months", "years"))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(type_of_pwd, value, fill = time_unit)) +
  geom_col(position = "dodge") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(legend.position = "bottom") +
  labs(y = "Duration taken to crack password", x = NULL) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set1", guide = guide_legend(nrow = 1)) +
  scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0, 0), limits = c(0, 60))

Based on the data, its better to have a password that’s alpha numeric as it has a higher password strength and would take longer to crack as compared to passwords that are only consisting of numeric or only characters.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description:
This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are:

  1. You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r});
  2. A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.

There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown. For example, you can write a task list with Blackfriday but not with Pandoc:

  • Write an R package.
  • Write a book.
  • …
  • Profit!

Similarly, Blackfriday does not support LaTeX math and Pandoc does. I have added the MathJax support to this theme ( hugo-lithium) but there is a caveat for plain Markdown posts: you have to include math expressions in a pair of backticks (inline: `$ $`; display style: `$$ $$`), e.g., $S_n = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i$.^[This is because we have to protect the math expressions from being interpreted as Markdown. You may not need the backticks if your math expression does not contain any special Markdown syntax such as underscores or asterisks, but it is always a safer choice to use backticks. When you happen to have a pair of literal dollar signs inside the same element, you can escape one dollar sign, e.g., \$50 and $100 renders “$50 and $100”.] For R Markdown posts, you do not need the backticks, because Pandoc can identify and process math expressions.

When creating a new post, you have to decide whether the post format is Markdown or R Markdown, and this can be done via the ext argument of the function blogdown::new_post(), e.g.

blogdown::new_post("Post Title", ext = '.Rmd')
